inputDescriptors.name: Accept untrusted SSL certificates
inputDescriptors.description:
Allows the SVN client to accept self-signed SSL server certificates without installing them into the Azure DevOps service role and/or Build Agent computers.

Same as the `--trust-server-cert` option of the `svn` command line utility.

inputDescriptors.name: Realm name
inputDescriptors.description:
If you use multiple credentials in a build pipeline to download a complete set of the source from Subversion, you should specify the `Realm name` in each of them. The `Realm name` represents a sort of "authentication namespace" used by the Subversion repository to select the appropriate Subversion identity database. Along with the repository server's schema, hostname, and port it forms a key that the build agent uses to select the specific credential from the set provided in the build pipeline.

To find out the `Realm name`, you could do any of the following:
  • If you access the repository via `HTTP` or `HTTPS`: Open the repo in a web browser without saved credentials. It will use the `Realm Name` in the authentication dialog.
  • Use the command line `svn` program. If you don't have stored the credentials, run e.g. `svn info https://svnserver/repo`. You will see the `Realm name` when it asks you to enter a password.
  • If you have already stored the credentials to access the repository, look for the `Realm name` in one of the files in the Subversion authentication cache section of your user profile, e.g. in `~/.subversion/auth/svn/simple` or `C:\Users\yourname\Application Data\Subversion\auth\svn.simple`.

inputDescriptors.name: Username
inputDescriptors.description: Username for connecting to the endpoint

inputDescriptors.name: Password
inputDescriptors.description: Password for connecting to the endpoint

value.name: subversion
value.description: Service connection type for all Subversion connections

endpointUrl.helpText:
If you use this authentication credential as a main Subversion repository service connection, you should specify the full repository URL, e.g. `https://svnserver/repo` or `svn://svnserver:3690/repositories/myrepo`. The `Realm name` parameter is optional in this case.

If you use this authentication credential as an additional service connection for Subversion externals, you may specify the schema, hostname, and port only, e.g. `https://svnserver:443` or `svn://svnserver:3690`. The `Realm name` parameter is required in this case.

inputDescriptors.name: Client Certificate
inputDescriptors.description:
Base64 encoding of the cluster's client certificate file.

You can use the following PowerShell script to obtain a Base64-encoded representation of a certificate:
[System.Convert]::ToBase64String([System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes("C:\path\to\certificate.pfx"))
